topics.title: The Double Diamond: Diverge, Converge, Repeat

hook.text: The British Design Council mapped how designers actually work: two diamonds â€” first find the right problem, then the.

topics.title: Wicked Problems: When Design Thinking Meets Chaos

hook.text: How do you solve poverty? Climate change? Healthcare inequality?

buildup.text: Horst Rittel coined 'wicked problems' in 1973 â€” problems with no clear definition, no stopping rule, and no right.

discovery.text: Each attempt to solve a wicked problem changes the problem itself.

twist.text: Traditional engineering approaches fail on wicked problems. They need design thinking's iterative, empathetic.

climax.text: You can't 'solve' wicked problems. You can only improve them â€” continuously, iteratively, and humbly.

punchline.text: Some problems can't be solved. They can only be managed â€” wisely and endlessly.

quiz.question: What defines a 'wicked problem'?
options: It has no clear definition, no stopping rule, and changes when addressed

topics.title: IDEO's Shopping Cart: Design Thinking in 5 Days

hook.text: In 1999, ABC Nightline challenged IDEO to redesign the shopping cart in five days.

buildup.text: IDEO's team spent day one ONLY observing â€” watching shoppers, interviewing store workers, studying pain points.

discovery.text: They found the real problems: child safety, theft, navigation in crowded aisles â€” issues no engineer would identify.

twist.text: The final design was modular â€” removable baskets, better turning radius, child seats. Not futuristic-looking.

climax.text: The episode became the most-referenced design thinking case study in business schools worldwide â€” watched by millions.

punchline.text: Five days. One shopping cart. A permanent change in how the world thinks about.

topics.title: Design Thinking vs. Traditional Problem Solving

hook.text: Traditional problem-solving: define â†’ analyze â†’ solve. Design thinking: empathize â†’ define â†’ ideate â†’ prototype â†’ test.

buildup.text: Traditional approaches assume the problem is clear. Design thinking assumes the problem itself needs to be discovered.

discovery.text: Traditional methods optimize existing solutions. Design thinking reimagines what the solution could be â€” often.

twist.text: Neither is universally better. For known problems (fix this bridge), traditional wins.

topics.title: Accessibility Pioneer: Vint Cerf and the Internet's Deaf Co-Creator

topics.title: The Innovator's Dilemma: Why Success Breeds Failure

hook.text: Kodak invented the digital camera in 1975 â€” then buried it to protect film profits. They filed for bankruptcy in 2012.
